Message.Msg: I've been clear that I've lost a lot in Amazon. I gave up all my CMG gains and then some. That's okay. I'll make my money from building companies that pioneer new technologies which actually create value and make the world a better place for my kids. Some of us have knowledge and skills that matters for the real economy. Your daytrading skills won't help you much in the future as financial assets collapse in real terms.

Topic.Title: Let's try to focus on some content...

Message.Msg: AJ & NAS: Why don't you try to focus on some content? Fundamentals? Facts? You're plenty focused on attacking others, yet offer nothing of substance or value. NAS's big insight is that QE lifts the market (except for stocks like AAPL that have been crushed despite solid fundies... don't worry about that counterfactual). I haven't even seen that level of intellectual content from A/J on this board, but maybe he does so on other boards. So fellas, how high is it going? What is Amazon going to earn next year? How much true DISCRETIONARY FCF?

Topic.Title: And before you take anything from Techstrategy's repeated, pompous, bloviating, you might want to look back about a year

Message.Msg: I agree. Don't take my word for it. Go to the quaterly reports and check the net working capital trends over time. Look at what happens in Q3 and Q4. Check that Amazon used only half of its $3B raise to buy the building. Or, look back at my other posts on fundamental economics (fuel price correlations, gross shipping cost as a % of net sales, net margin $ per shipment as KPI, etc) and tear them apart. Go after the substance. Challenge me on the facts and analysis. I welcome it. If you do, I suspect you'll conclude that this is a trading scam. Someday, Bethany McLean will write a tome on this...

Topic.Title: Shop By Local: Find national brands, locally, with the worlds most relevant local search engine, Krillion

Message.Msg: Merriman Capita in the report over 17 sites. "The More "Profitable" Network Publishing & Advertising Business As we mentioned above Local Corp. has established strong relationships with regional publishing companies across the county, such as the Boston Herald, the Washington Post, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, and many others. The company arranges to link its proprietary search engine into these publishers online web pages in order to respond to customers who surf the site in search of local information, events, activities and shopping. These searches are almost always of a local nature and the people are favorably disposed to act on the information they receive. As such the local advertisers are much more willing to pay more for "click thrus" from these prospects.

Topic.Title: Tech - youre right again....

Message.Msg: Sybs: I've often been wrong on short to mid term price movement. I'm not a good trader. But, I'm rarely wrong on fundamentals economic analysis. I'd be happy to look at any source for your "well founded" assertion. I'll simply refer you to the AEO2013 report which shows that we have a LONG way to go for energy independence. ****** Oil production, particularly from tight oil plays, rises over the next decade, leading to a reduction in net import dependence Crude oil production has increased since 2008, reversing a decline that began in 1986. From 5.0 million barrels per day in 2008, U.S. crude oil production increased to 6.5 million barrels per day in 2012. Improvements in advanced crude oil production technologies continues to lift domestic supply, with domestic production of crude oil increasing in the Reference case before declining gradually beginning in 2020 for the remainder of the projection period. The projected growth results largely from a significant increase in onshore crude oil production, particularly from shale and other tight formations, which has been spurred by technological advances and relatively high oil prices. Tight oil development is still at an early stage, and the outlook is highly uncertain. In some of the AEO2013 alternative cases, tight oil production and total U.S. crude oil production are significantly above their levels in the Reference case. The net import share of U.S. petroleum and other liquids consumption (including crude oil, petroleum liquids, and liquids derived from nonpetroleum sources) grew steadily from the mid-1980s to 2005 but has fallen in every year since then (Figure 1). In the Reference case, U.S. net imports of petroleum and other liquids decline through 2019, while still providing approximately one-third of total U.S. supply. The net import share of U.S. petroleum and other liquids consumption continues to decline in the Reference case, falling to 34 percent in 2019 before increasing to 37 percent in 2040.

Topic.Title: Tech - youre right again....

Message.Msg: Sybs: I am commercializing two energy technologies, one of which is liquid fuels based. There's a reason oil and gas prices are stubbornly high despite domestic demand dropping... And when people talk about being energy independent in 2030, they always fail to mention the market clearing price... For those that are intellectually curious, there is an interesting IMF working paper that explores the impact of a drop in trend production growth to 1%. Read it and you'll develop a better understanding of what is in store for the global economy.
